images.copyright: Whooper swans, Kotoku Pond, Japan (© Martin Bailey/Shutterstock)
images.title: Whoop, there they fly
images.caption: Whooper swans, Kotoku Pond, Japan
images.desc: In Japan's colder months, there's a morning moment when stillness breaks—not with wind or footsteps, but with a bright, rolling call that sweeps across the water. Whooper swans have touched down. One loud whoop—and winter suddenly feels awake. These birds migrate from Siberia and the Russian Far East, choosing Japan as their seasonal home because its lakes offer what long-distance travellers crave: open water, steady food and a safe place to rest. One of their favourite destinations is Kotoku Pond in the Kantō region on Japan's largest island.

og.title: Whooper swans, Kotoku Pond, Japan

images.copyright: St. Gregory Church in Ani Ruins, Kars, Türkiye (© Kenan Talas/Getty Images)
images.title: The church that outlived a city
images.caption: St. Gregory Church in Ani Ruins, Kars, Türkiye
images.desc: On a windswept plateau in eastern Türkiye, along the border with Armenia, the ruins of the ancient city of Ani rise from the landscape with striking clarity. A millennium ago, Ani was a thriving Armenian capital on a major Silk Road route, its fortifications and busy streets shaping trade and culture across the region. Today, the city is quiet, but its outline still carries the weight of its past.
images.bsTitle: The church that outlived a city

og.title: St. Gregory Church in Ani Ruins, Kars, Türkiye

images.copyright: Black-and-white ruffed lemur in Madagascar (© Cyrielle Beaubois/Getty Images)
images.title: What remains wild
images.caption: Black-and-white ruffed lemur in Madagascar
images.desc: One moment the canopy is still, and the next, a burst of black and white shoots through it like a living exclamation mark. That's the black-and-white ruffed lemur, a primate that doesn't shy away from announcing itself with raucous calls. Its coat comes in bold patches, and the thick ruff frames its face. Roughly 92% of the lemur's diet is fruit, with leaves, nectar, seeds and the occasional fungus making up the rest. When trees are heavy with figs and other seasonal offerings, this creature moves quickly through the dense forest. As it laps up nectar, pollen sticks to its snout, turning it into one of the habitat's most effective pollinators.

og.title: Black-and-white ruffed lemur in Madagascar
og.desc: One moment the canopy is still, and the next, a burst of black and white shoots through it like a living exclamation mark. That's the black…

images.copyright: Plate ice along Lake Superior, Grand Marais, Minnesota, United States (© wanderluster/Getty Images)
images.title: Shards of winter
images.caption: Plate ice along Lake Superior, Grand Marais, Minnesota, United States
images.desc: When winter tightens its grip on Lake Superior in Minnesota, the shoreline transforms into a landscape of tilted, glass-like shards known as plate ice. Thin sheets fracture under shifting temperatures, then drift and stack as the wind presses them toward land. The result is a field of translucent blues and silvers, catching the light at sharp angles and making the water's edge appear sculpted rather than frozen.

images.copyright: Salisbury Cathedral, Wiltshire, England (© Julian Elliott Photography/Getty Images)
images.title: Unboxed traditions
images.caption: Boxing Day
images.desc: The best thing about Boxing Day is that it doesn't ask much of you. No big countdown. No dramatic unwrapping. No last-minute dashes for batteries. It's a rare holiday that says, 'Sit down, finish your leftovers and take a moment.' Celebrated on December 26 in Canada, United Kingdom and some Commonwealth countries, it's a national cool-down after Christmas has done all the heavy lifting. The term goes back to Victorian Britain, when households prepared Christmas boxes for workers and tradespeople—tokens of thanks that ranged from coins to essentials. Churches joined in by opening alms boxes and distributing donations.

og.title: Boxing Day
og.desc: The best thing about Boxing Day is that it doesn't ask much of you. No big countdown. No dramatic unwrapping. No last-minute dashes for…

images.copyright: Christmas trees in Old Quebec (© Jean Surprenant/Getty Images)
images.title: Christmas couture
images.caption: Merry Christmas!
images.desc: Under a crisp Canadian winter sky, it's the glow of Christmas trees—on city squares, on neighbourhood lawns and in living-room windows—that sets the season alight. From Toronto's Cavalcade of Lights to Vancouver's Festival of Lights at VanDusen Garden, communities gather around these lit evergreens, sharing warmth during the year's coldest weeks. Christmas—a celebration of faith, light and togetherness—invites people to bring that brightness indoors. Garlands wind through hallways, candles cast a soft glow across familiar rooms and mistletoe hangs in doorways while wreaths greet guests at the front door.

og.title: Merry Christmas!
og.desc: Under a crisp Canadian winter sky, it's the glow of Christmas trees—on city squares, on neighbourhood lawns and in living-room windows—that…

images.copyright: Snowy chapel with Christmas tree in the Bavarian Alps, Germany (© mauritius images GmbH/Alamy)
images.title: Traditions that travel
images.caption: Christmas Eve
images.desc: As Christmas Eve arrives, millions embrace customs that connect us to our roots—or introduce us to entirely new cultures. In snowy regions like the Bavarian Alps in Germany—a frost-kissed landscape seen in today's image—festive lights glow against winter's chill. Elsewhere, the sun blazes brightly: think of the Caribbean, Australia or Brazil, where Christmas often means golden beaches instead of frosty mornings.

images.copyright: Reindeer during winter snowfall, Lapland, Finland (© Roberto Moiola/Getty Images)
images.title: Where holiday magic runs on hooves
images.caption: Reindeer, Lapland, Finland
images.desc: Few creatures evoke the magic of the holidays quite like the reindeer. Also known as caribou, they are the spirit animals of Christmas lovers—and they rock it. Sturdy and sure-footed, they've been pulling Santa's sleigh ever since Clement Clarke Moore cast them in the role in his 1823 poem 'A Visit from Saint Nicholas.' And they were born for it. Their hooves shrink in winter to expose a gripping rim, then expand in warmer months for better traction.
images.bsTitle: Where holiday magic runs on hooves
